<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 187, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 207, 280, 221]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 248, 600, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 313, 386, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 343, 235, 356]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 504, 371]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 372, 890, 400]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 382, 414]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 429, 890, 458]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 458, 890, 473]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 488, 555, 503]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 517, 764, 530]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 532, 416, 546]]<|/det|>
Any working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 547, 359, 561]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>

There is significant air resistance. The acceleration of free fall is \(g\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 828, 135]]<|/det|> When the stone is falling at a constant (terminal) velocity, which information is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 755, 308]]<|/det|>

Dzero\(mg\)zero

It takes a time of 3.20 s to return to her hand. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 708, 408, 724]]<|/det|> Assume air resistance is negligible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 737, 560, 754]]<|/det|> What is the initial speed with which the ball is thrown? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 765, 735, 783]]<|/det|> **A** \(3.07m s^{-1}\) **B** \(7.85m s^{-1}\) **C** \(15.7m s^{-1}\) **D** \(31.4m s^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 767, 90]]<|/det|>
In which example is it not possible for the underlined body to be in equilibrium?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 460, 118]]<|/det|>
A An aeroplane climbs at a steady rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 555, 144]]<|/det|>
B An aeroplane tows a glider at a constant altitude.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 580, 170]]<|/det|>
C A speedboat changes direction at a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 438, 196]]<|/det|>
D Two boats tow a ship into harbour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 225, 107, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 919, 287]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(1100\mathrm{kg}\) is travelling at a constant speed of \(15\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) up a slope inclined at \(10^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The combined frictional forces acting on the car are directed down the slope and are equal to \(\frac{W}{5}\) , where \(W\) is the weight of the car.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[254, 304, 740, 396]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 407, 546, 425]]<|/det|>
What is the useful output power of the car's engine?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 435, 718, 453]]<|/det|>
A 28kW B 32kW C 60kW D 190kW

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 481, 107, 498]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 481, 919, 513]]<|/det|>
An old-fashioned 60W lamp converts \(95\%\) of its energy supply into heat. A 4.0W modern lamp has the same power output of light as the old-fashioned lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 526, 470, 543]]<|/det|>
What is the efficiency of the modern lamp?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 554, 693, 571]]<|/det|>
A 5.0% B 6.7% C 75% D 95%

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 720, 90]]<|/det|>
A bead is released from rest at point P and slides along a wire, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 101, 816, 260]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 270, 918, 303]]<|/det|>
The track loops around and forms a vertical circle of diameter \(40 \text{cm}\). At point Q, the bead has a speed of \(1.4 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 316, 546, 333]]<|/det|>
Air resistance and friction on the wire are negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 346, 560, 363]]<|/det|>
What is the height \(h\) from which the bead is released?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 374, 712, 390]]<|/det|>
**A** \(0.30 \text{m}\) **B** \(0.40 \text{m}\) **C** \(0.50 \text{m}\) **D** \(0.60 \text{m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 420, 106, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 918, 467]]<|/det|>
A small diesel engine uses a volume of \(1.5 \times 10^{4} \text{cm}^{3}\) of fuel per hour to produce a useful power output of \(40 \text{kW}\). It may be assumed that \(34 \text{kJ}\) of energy is transferred to the engine when it uses \(1.0 \text{cm}^{3}\) of fuel.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 481, 683, 497]]<|/det|>
What is the rate of transfer from the engine of energy that is wasted?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 509, 718, 526]]<|/det|>
**A** \(102 \text{kW}\) **B** \(142 \text{kW}\) **C** \(182 \text{kW}\) **D** \(470 \text{kW}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Two boxes X and Y have the same mass. Box X is lifted vertically through a height \(h\) by a force of magnitude \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 920, 150]]<|/det|>
Box Y is pulled along a slope by a force of the same magnitude to reach the same height, as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 157, 777, 305]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 349, 336]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 139, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 348, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
Both boxes gain the same amount of gravitational potential energy and the same amount of work is done by the two forces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 139, 407]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 390, 920, 422]]<|/det|>
Both boxes gain the same amount of gravitational potential energy but more work is done by the force acting on box Y than by the force acting on box X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 431, 139, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 431, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
Box Y gains less gravitational potential energy than box X because the weight of box Y is less than the weight of box X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 472, 139, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 472, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
Box Y gains more gravitational potential energy than box X as more work is done by the force acting on box Y than by the force acting on box X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 532, 107, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 532, 544, 548]]<|/det|>
The force-extension graph of a metal wire is shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 561, 735, 578]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 272, 713, 289]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 920, 333]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 343, 600, 375]]<|/det|>

The wave is shown on a graph of displacement \(x\) against distance \(d\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 397, 135]]<|/det|> Which graph is correctly labelled? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 145, 860, 472]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 500, 107, 518]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 918, 533]]<|/det|> The table lists possible orders of magnitude of the wavelengths of some of the principal radiations of the electromagnetic spectrum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 695, 562]]<|/det|> Which row shows the correct orders of magnitude of the wavelengths? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 574, 682, 725]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 111, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 919, 104]]<|/det|>
A vehicle carries a microwave transmitter that emits microwaves of a constant frequency. A stationary observer has a microwave receiver.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 919, 149]]<|/det|>
The vehicle moves directly towards the observer at constant speed. The observer detects microwaves of frequency \(F_{\mathrm{o}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 919, 194]]<|/det|>
The vehicle then accelerates, still moving towards the observer, travels at higher steady speed for a time and then decelerates until it stops.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 208, 866, 224]]<|/det|>
What is the variation in the frequency of the microwaves that are detected by the observer?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 236, 144, 253]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 236, 845, 253]]<|/det|>
The observed frequency will fall, then remain steady then return to the frequency \(F_{\mathrm{o}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 262, 144, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 262, 905, 279]]<|/det|>
The observed frequency will fall, then remain steady then rise to a higher frequency than \(F_{\mathrm{o}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 144, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 900, 305]]<|/det|>
The observed frequency will rise, then remain steady then fall to a lower frequency than \(F_{\mathrm{o}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 315, 850, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 314, 850, 330]]<|/det|>
The observed frequency will rise, then remain steady then return to the frequency \(F_{\mathrm{o}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 359, 107, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 359, 803, 376]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a cathode-ray oscilloscope display of an electromagnetic wave.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 388, 652, 513]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 526, 425, 543]]<|/det|>
The time base setting is \(0.20 \mu \text{s} \text{cm}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 558, 350, 573]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 586, 141, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 586, 799, 617]]<|/det|>
The frequency of the wave is \(2.5 \text{MHz}\) and it lies in the microwave region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 628, 141, 645]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 628, 801, 658]]<|/det|>
The frequency of the wave is \(2.5 \text{MHz}\) and it lies in the radio-wave region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 669, 149, 686]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 669, 799, 700]]<|/det|>
The frequency of the wave is \(5.0 \text{MHz}\) and it lies in the microwave region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 710, 149, 726]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 710, 801, 740]]<|/det|>
The frequency of the wave is \(5.0 \text{MHz}\) and it lies in the radio-wave region of the electromagnetic spectrum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 770, 107, 788]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 770, 919, 801]]<|/det|>
In a double-slit interference experiment, light of frequency \(6.0 \times 10^{14} \text{Hz}\) is incident on a pair of slits. Bright fringes that are \(3.0 \text{mm}\) apart are observed on a screen some distance away.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 815, 919, 846]]<|/det|>
What is the separation of the bright fringes when the frequency of the light is changed to \(5.0 \times 10^{14} \text{Hz}\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 859, 148, 876]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 859, 217, 876]]<|/det|>
1.8mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 859, 384, 876]]<|/det|>
B 2.5mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 859, 551, 876]]<|/det|>
C 3.0mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 859, 718, 876]]<|/det|>
D 3.6mm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Monochromatic light is incident on a pair of narrow slits a distance of \(0.1 \text{mm}\) apart. A series of bright and dark fringes are observed on a screen a distance of \(2.0 \text{m}\) away. The distance between adjacent bright fringes is \(8.0 \text{mm}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 131, 885, 313]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 325, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
What is the path difference between the light waves from the two slits that meet at the second order dark fringe?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 369, 255, 385]]<|/det|>
A \(2.0\times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{m}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 255, 412]]<|/det|>
B \(4.0\times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{m}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 424, 255, 440]]<|/det|>
C \(6.0\times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{m}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 255, 467]]<|/det|>
D \(8.0\times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{m}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 495, 104, 513]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 495, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
A tube of length \(L\) is open at both ends. A stationary wave is set up in this tube when a tuning fork vibrating with frequency \(f_{\mathrm{x}}\) is held at one end. This is the lowest frequency of stationary wave that can be formed in this tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
Another tube of length \(2L\) is closed at one end. A stationary wave is set up in this tube when a tuning fork vibrating with frequency \(f_{\mathrm{y}}\) is held at the open end. This is the lowest frequency of stationary wave that can be formed in this tube.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 612, 743, 812]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 823, 560, 840]]<|/det|>
Assume the end correction for each tube is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 853, 339, 869]]<|/det|>
Which equation is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 880, 140, 901]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 880, 757, 910]]<|/det|>
\(f_{\mathrm{x}} = \frac{f_{\mathrm{y}}}{4}\) B \(f_{\mathrm{x}} = \frac{f_{\mathrm{y}}}{2}\) C \(f_{\mathrm{x}} = 2f_{\mathrm{y}}\) D \(f_{\mathrm{x}} = 4f_{\mathrm{y}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 674, 90]]<|/det|>
Which statement gives a condition that enables diffraction to occur?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 140, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 101, 620, 119]]<|/det|>
A source of waves moves towards a stationary observer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 141, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 127, 502, 144]]<|/det|>
A wave is partially blocked by an obstacle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 154, 141, 171]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 153, 463, 170]]<|/det|>
Two coherent waves are superposed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 141, 197]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 180, 918, 211]]<|/det|>
Two waves of equal speed and frequency are travelling through the same part of a medium in opposite directions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 240, 107, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>30</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 240, 918, 272]]<|/det|>
An electron passes into the space between two parallel plates that are \(5.0 \text{cm}\) apart and which are maintained at electric potentials of \(+2000 \text{V}\) and \(-500 \text{V}\), respectively.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 281, 697, 399]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 412, 460, 428]]<|/det|>
What is the electric force on the electron?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 440, 260, 535]]<|/det|>
<pre>A \(1.6 \times 10^{-15} \text{N}\) B \(4.8 \times 10^{-15} \text{N}\) C \(6.4 \times 10^{-15} \text{N}\) D \(8.0 \times 10^{-15} \text{N}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 565, 107, 583]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 565, 773, 583]]<|/det|>
Which statement about electric charges in a uniform electric field is **not** correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 140, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 594, 918, 625]]<|/det|>
Electric charges of the same magnitude, whether positive or negative, experience the same magnitude of force when placed in the same uniform electric field.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 635, 140, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 635, 918, 666]]<|/det|>
The direction of the force on a positive charge placed in a uniform electric field is independent of the magnitude of the charge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 676, 140, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 676, 918, 707]]<|/det|>
The magnitude of the force on a positive charge placed in a uniform electric field is proportional to the magnitude of the electric field strength.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 718, 138, 736]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 718, 918, 749]]<|/det|>
The work done to move a positive charge a certain distance in a uniform electric field is independent of the direction of the movement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 413, 90]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a simple circuit.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 100, 606, 197]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 210, 349, 226]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 238, 139, 255]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 238, 918, 270]]<|/det|>
When switch S is closed, the e.m.f. of the battery falls because work is done against the internal resistance of the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 279, 139, 295]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 279, 918, 310]]<|/det|>
When switch S is closed, the e.m.f. of the battery falls because work is done against the resistance of R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 139, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 320, 918, 352]]<|/det|>
When switch S is closed, the potential difference across the battery falls because work is done against the internal resistance of the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 361, 139, 377]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 361, 918, 393]]<|/det|>
When switch S is closed, the potential difference across the battery falls because work is done against the resistance of R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 420, 107, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 918, 469]]<|/det|>
A resistor has resistance \(R\) .When the potential difference across the resistor is \(V,\) the current in the resistor is \(I\) . The power dissipated in the resistor is \(P\) .Work \(W\) is done when charge \(Q\) flows through the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 482, 588, 498]]<|/det|>
What is not a valid relationship between these variables?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 508, 712, 536]]<|/det|>
<pre>A \(I = \frac{P}{V}\)  <pre>B \(Q = \frac{W}{V}\)  <pre>C \(R = \frac{P}{I^2}\)  <pre>D \(R = \frac{V}{P}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 570, 107, 587]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 570, 577, 586]]<|/det|>
A wire of resistance \(9.55 \Omega\) has a diameter of \(0.280 \text{mm}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 600, 509, 616]]<|/det|>
It is made of metal of resistivity \(4.90 \times 10^{-7} \Omega \cdot \text{m}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 630, 370, 647]]<|/det|>
What is the length of the wire?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 658, 712, 675]]<|/det|>
<pre>A \(1.20 \text{m}\)  <pre>B \(4.80 \text{m}\)  <pre>C \(19.0 \text{m}\)  <pre>D \(76.8 \text{m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 704, 107, 721]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 704, 918, 736]]<|/det|>
Charge carriers, each of charge \(q\) , move along a wire of fixed length. The number density of the charge carriers in the wire is \(n\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 750, 918, 781]]<|/det|>
What is also required, for this wire, to determine the average drift velocity of the charge carriers in terms of \(n\) and \(q\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 793, 470, 808]]<|/det|>
<pre>A current per unit of cross-sectional area

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 819, 455, 834]]<|/det|>
<pre>B potential difference per unit of length

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 844, 447, 859]]<|/det|>
<pre>C resistance and cross-sectional area

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 870, 324, 885]]<|/det|>
<pre>D resistivity and length

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|> A potential divider circuit is constructed with one variable resistor X and one fixed resistor Y, as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 114, 610, 284]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 293, 881, 311]]<|/det|> The potential difference across resistor X is \(V_{X}\) and the potential difference of resistor Y is \(V_{Y}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 323, 666, 341]]<|/det|> As the resistance of X is increased, what happens to \(V_{X}\) and to \(V_{Y}\)? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 484, 481]]<|/det|>

Afallsrises

Crisesfalls
Drisesstays the same

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|>

Five resistors are connected as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 268, 148, 285]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

0.25Ω

B 0.61Ω

C 4.0Ω

D 16Ω

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 314, 107, 333]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 314, 918, 346]]<|/det|>
A nucleus of neptunium-236 contains 93 protons and 143 neutrons. This nucleus decays with the emission of an \(\alpha\) -particle. The nucleus formed then emits a \(\beta^{- }\) particle.
